style="text-align: left;">Generate encryption key using PBKDF2 hashing function:</li><ol><li style="text-align: left;">master password (As key)</li><li style="text-align: left;">salt (as salt key)</li></ol><li style="text-align: left;">Create secrete key</li><li style="text-align: left;">Generate encrypted secrete key and encrypt this using aes-256-cbc Advance encryption standard. With encryption&nbsp;key as key and secrete key as data</li><li style="text-align: left;">At last store these 3 values:&nbsp;</li><ol><li style="text-align: left;">hashed master password</li><li style="text-align: left;">encrypted secrete&nbsp;key</li><li style="text-align: left;">salt key</li></ol><li style="text-align: left;">Delete verification token<br></li></ol>" style="shape=process;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;backgroundOutline=1;size=0.029411764705882353;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="1030" y="1129" width="340" height="280" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="wTH0yocXQ4WSepD2pJDL-44" value="User Verification Completed" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="1040" y="1459" width="320" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="wTH0yocXQ4WSepD2pJDL-57" value="<h1 style="margin-top: 0px;">How BCRYPT works</h1><p></p><ol><li>Salting: A random salt is generated and added to the password.&nbsp; &nbsp;</li><li>Key Stretching: The combined password and salt are subjected to a computationally expensive process, involving multiple iterations determined by the work factor. This significantly increases the time required to crack the password.&nbsp; &nbsp;</li><li>Hash Generation: The result of the key stretching process is used to generate a fixed-length hash.</li><li>A typical Bcrypt hash looks like this:$2a$10$vI1UF0Nt3JAuhVo0O2QzpuF6j3LUdAu9u01L9qLJ6519rHt00j4u.<br></li></ol><p></p>" style="text;html=1;whiteSpace=wrap;overflow=hidden;rounded=0;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="38.5" y="1120" width="460" height="190" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="wTH0yocXQ4WSepD2pJDL-58" value="<h1 style="margin-top: 0px;">How PBKDF2 works</h1><p></p><ol><li>Salting: A unique salt is generated for each password. This prevents rainbow table attacks.&nbsp; &nbsp;</li><li>Iteration: The password and salt are combined and fed into the PRF (often HMAC). This process is repeated a specified number of times (iteration count).&nbsp; &nbsp;</li><li>Key derivation: The output of the final iteration is used to derive the key.</li></ol><p></p>" style="text;html=1;whiteSpace=wrap;overflow=hidden;rounded=0;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="40" y="1339" width="390" height="181" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="wTH0yocXQ4WSepD2pJDL-59" value="<h1 style="margin-top: 0px;">How AES-256-CBC Works</h1><p></p><ol><li>Initialization Vector (IV): A random value is generated to initialize the encryption process.<span style="background-color: initial;">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></li><li>Block Division: The plaintext is divided into blocks of a fixed size (usually 128 bits for AES).&nbsp; &nbsp;</li><li>XOR with Previous Ciphertext: The first plaintext block is XORed with the IV. Subsequent blocks are XORed with the previous ciphertext block.&nbsp; &nbsp;</li><li>AES Encryption: Each XORed block is encrypted using the 256-bit AES key.</li><li>Output: The encrypted blocks form the ciphertext.</li></ol><p></p>" style="text;html=1;whiteSpace=wrap;overflow=hidden;rounded=0;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="40" y="1550" width="434" height="191" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="wTH0yocXQ4WSepD2pJDL-60" value="<h1 style="margin-top: 0px;">How&nbsp;encrypted secrete key created</h1><div>Unlike hashed master password creating encrypted secrete key we use PBKDF2 hashing function here <b>master password</b> used as key and <span style="background-color: initial;"><b>salt key</b> generated using random bytes 16 length convert them bin2Hex with this we get <b><u>"</u></b></span><b><u><span style="background-color: initial;">encryption key</span><span style="background-color: initial;">"</span></u></b></div><div><b><u><span style="background-color: initial;"><br></span></u></b></div><div>Now we create <b>Secrete key</b> this used as <b>data </b>and generated&nbsp;<span style="background-color: initial;"><span style="background-color: initial;"><b style=""><u>encryption key</u>&nbsp;</b>as key with these value we encrypt&nbsp;</span></span><b style="background-color: initial;">Secrete key&nbsp;</b><span style="background-color: initial;"><span style="background-color: initial;">using&nbsp;</span></span><span style="background-color: initial;"><b>aes-256-cbc </b>and then stored in backend.</span></div><div><b><u><span style="background-color: initial;"><br></span></u></b></div>" style="text;html=1;whiteSpace=wrap;overflow=hidden;rounded=0;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="560" y="1250" width="434" height="190" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="wTH0yocXQ4WSepD2pJDL-61" value="<h1 style="margin-top: 0px;">How hashed master password created</h1><p>By using BCRYPT hash function we create this and store this in backend. When user login we will compare this with user entered input</p>" style="text;html=1;whiteSpace=wrap;overflow=hidden;rounded=0;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="560" y="1120" width="440" hashed master password

ol.li: Salting: A random salt is generated and added to the password.

Key Stretching: The combined password and salt are subjected to a computationally expensive process, involving multiple iterations determined by the work factor. This significantly increases the time required to crack the password.
Hash Generation: The result of the key stretching process is used to generate a fixed-length hash.
A typical Bcrypt hash looks like this:$2a$10$vI1UF0Nt3JAuhVo0O2QzpuF6j3LUdAu9u01L9qLJ6519rHt00j4u.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 388px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1256px; margin-left: 3px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 177px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

ol.li: Salting: A unique salt is generated for each password. This prevents rainbow table attacks.
Iteration: The password and salt are combined and fed into the PRF (often HMAC). This process is repeated a specified number of times (iteration count).
Key derivation: The output of the final iteration is used to derive the key.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 432px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1467px; margin-left: 3px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 187px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

ol.li: Initialization Vector (IV): A random value is generated to initialize the encryption process.
Block Division: The plaintext is divided into blocks of a fixed size (usually 128 bits for AES).
XOR with Previous Ciphertext: The first plaintext block is XORed with the IV. Subsequent blocks are XORed with the previous ciphertext block.
AES Encryption: Each XORed block is encrypted using the 256-bit AES key.
Output: The encrypted blocks form the ciphertext.

Now we create Secrete key this used as data and generatedencryption keyas key with these value we encryptSecrete keyusingaes-256-cbc and then stored in backend.
